bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, February 11, 1924

div1.p: [Carter] writes about the conveyance of yellow fever between Africa and Brazil.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Frederick F. Russell, February 11, 1924
div1.opener:
I. H. B.
1) Brazil (conveyance of
(Y.f. between, & Africa)
2) “o bicho”
/LC
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
February 11, 1924.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p: I was glad to get the letter you sent me from White.

I knew Dr. Noguchi would do you good in Brazil and he has
done so. Latin America is very appreciative of good scientific
work--especially in one not a “yanqui”--far less so of good executive
work.

As to the conveyance of yellow fever from Brazil to Africa,
I note in Flu's paper--sent me with those on Guiana some time ago--
that he claimed that German West Africa (Togo Land) had been in-
fected from America in 1896; I don't know whether from Brazil or not,
and there is evidence (not proof) that the first epidemic in Brazil
(“o bicho” of Recife and Bahia: 16846 or /86, I forget which) came
from Africa (Saõ Thiago in the Azores) by the fleet of Freire Andrade,
so there is no reason she shouldn't “pay back.”

Don't let your Brazilian men deceive you: “o bicho”
now in Brazil is quite certainly the Schistosomiasis mansoni, but that
which Father da Rocha Pitta described in Bahia in 1686 was yellow fever.
The word, “o bicho” simply means “the creature” and in a derogatory
sense, as we would say “the varmint.”

I am glad--extremely glad--that Dr. Mapleson, Assistant
Director of the Research Laboratory at Freetown, Sierra Leone, has
read something later than the report of the Commission of the Pas-
teur Institute at Rio, 1904. He is willing to admit that “it is now
an established fact that “S. fasciata” in an infective stage bites as
readily by day as by night” and is the first man writing from Africa
who has not laid great stress upon protection by night only--the same
is true of the physicians in Spanish America who follow blindly the
French school. I never read anything else.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Dr. F. F. Russell,
General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway,
New York, N. Y.
